description: From Middle English hose (“leggings, hose”), from Old English hose, hosa (“hose, leggings”), from Proto-West Germanic *hosā, from Proto-Germanic *husǭ (“coverings, leggings, trousers”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)kewH- (“to cover”).

nouns.description: hose (countable and uncountable, plural hoses or hosen)

entries.meaning: (countable) A flexible tube conveying water or other fluid.
(uncountable) A stocking-like garment worn on the legs; pantyhose, women's tights.
(obsolete) Close-fitting trousers or breeches, reaching to the knee.

verbs.description: hose (third-person singular simple present hoses, present participle hosing, simple past and past participle hosed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To water or spray with a hose.
(transitive) To spray as if with a hose; to spray in great quantity.
(transitive, computing) To break a computer so everything needs to be reinstalled; to wipe all files.
(transitive, sports) To cause an unfair disadvantage to a player or team through poor officiating; especially, to cause a player or team to lose the game with an incorrect call.
